name: Alstonia scholaris
Relationship: Compare: Similar in action to ALSTONIA CONSTRICTA, the bitter bark or native quinine of Australia. DITIN. (active principle, is anti-periodic, like quinine, but without unpleasant effects). CINCHONA (similar in diarrhoea, chronic dyspepsia and debility). Hydrastis; Fe. cit. et chin.

Abdomen: Heat and irritation in lower bowels
Violent purging and cramp in bowels
Camp diarrhoea, bloody stool, dysentery; diarrhoea from bad water and malaria

details: Malarial disease, with diarrhoea, dysentery, anaemia, feeble digestion, are the general conditions suggesting this remedy. Characteristics are the gone sensation in stomach and sinking in abdomen, with debility. A TONIC AFTER EXHAUSTING FEVERS.
dosage: Tincture to third potency. Locally, for ulcers and rheumatic pains.
